trial_identification.studytitle: Improving New Parents' Understanding of a Trial. The INPUT Study.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Can we improve parents understanding of a hypothetical clinical trial by using positive versus negative language in information leaflets? Randomised trial within a face to face questionnaire study.

conditions.healthcondition: Willingness to participate in clinical trials

interventions.interventions: The INPUT study proposed uses a randomised 2 x 3 x 2 factorial design to compare 12 different versions of an information leaflet describing an imaginary clinical trial in preterm infants. Parents will be randomly assigned to read one of 12 combinations of contrasting descriptions of (1) background risk, (2) the primary endpoint and (3) risks of participation, using 'negative', 'neutral' or 'positive' language. Through a face-to-face questionnaire performed immediately after reading the leaflet, the study will evaluate the effects of these contrasting expressions on the parents' level of understanding of a hypothetical clinical trial, their level of anxiety and their willingness to participate in the trial.
interventions.comparator: 'Negative' language group such as 'death or disability' group versus 'positive' language group such as 'survival with normal ability'.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Parents' level of understanding of the hypothetical clinical trial will be measured using a previously validated questionnaire (Porteri et al, 2009) adapted for use in parents of newborn infants.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: During completion of a 30 minute face to face questionnaire immediately after reading the information leaflet.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Parents' level of anxiety will be measured using the previously validated StateÂ­ Trait Anxiety Inventory State (Spielberger et al, 1977; O'Brien et al, 2013).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During completion of a 30 minute face to face questionnaire immediately after reading the information leaflet.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Parents' willingness to participate in the hypothetical clinical trial will be measured on a five part Likert Scale ranging from very unlikely to participate to very likely to participate.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: During completion of a 30 minute face to face questionnaire immediately after reading the information leaflet.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
Eligible participants must fulfill at least one of the following criteria: (i) Pregnant women in the antenatal ward with a potential preterm pregnancy and their partners, (ii) Parents whose babies are in the NICU or Special Care Nursery receiving CPAP or less.
Women aged 18 - 49 years Men aged >18 years
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: People whose primary language is other than English (LOTE) Children and/or young people (ie. <18 years) People who clinicians identify as unsuitable for the study

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation using a computer program to generate random allocation to one of the 12 possible combinations of different wordings in the the three sections of the questionnaire.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: The range on the adapted Porteri Score is 0-16. Assuming a mean of 10 and a standard deviation of 3, a sample of 40 patients per group in the 3 arm comparison of different wordings in Section 2 of the questionnaire yields >80% power to detect a difference of 1 Standard Deviation in the adapted Porteri Score between groups. A sample of 60 patients per group in the 2 arm comparisons of different wordings in Sections 1 and 3 of the questionnaire yields >90% power to detect a difference of 1 SD in the adapted Porteri Score between groups.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Few studies have investigated how to improve parents' understanding of clinical trials they are asked to join or how to reduce any possible distress. The INPUT study proposed will explore the effect of positive, negative or neutral language on parents' understanding, stress and willingness to participate in clinical trials.
